column1: Chișinău is the most economically prosperous locality in Moldova and its largest transportation hub. Nearly a third of Moldova's population lives in the metro area.
The origin of the city's name is unclear. A theory suggests that the name may come from the archaic Romanian word chișla (meaning "spring"
column2: "source of water") and nouă ("new")
column3: because it was built around a small spring
column4: at the corner of Pușkin and Albișoara streets.The other version
column7: holds that the name was formed the same way as the name of Chișineu (alternative spelling: Chișinău) in Western Romania
column8: near the border with Hungary. Its Hungarian name is Kisjenő
column9: from which the Romanian name originates. Kisjenő comes from kis "small" and the Jenő
column10: one of the seven Hungarian tribes that entered the Carpathian Basin in 896. At least 24 other settlements are named after the Jenő tribe.Chișinău is known in Russian as Кишинёв (Kishinjóv)

column18: especially in written language. The city is also historically referred to as German: Kischinau

column1: Two other waves of deportations of Moldova's native population were carried out by the Soviets
column2: the first one immediately after the Soviet reoccupation of Bessarabia until the end of the 1940s
column3: and the second one in the mid-1950s.In the years 1947 to 1949 the architect Alexey Shchusev developed a plan with the aid of a team of architects for the gradual reconstruction of the city.There was rapid population growth in the 1950s
column4: to which the Soviet administration responded by constructing large-scale housing and palaces in the style of Stalinist architecture. This process continued under Nikita Khrushchev
column5: who called for construction under the slogan "good
column6: cheaper and built faster". The new architectural style brought about dramatic change and generated the style that dominates today
column7: with large blocks of flats arranged in considerable settlements. These Khrushchev-era building are often informally called Khrushchyovka.

column1: The city lies in central Moldova and is surrounded by a relatively level landscape with very fertile ground.
Chișinău has a humid continental climate (Köppen climate classification Dfa) characterised by warm summers and cool
column2: windy winters. Winter minimum temperatures are often below 0 °C (32 °F)
column3: although they rarely drop below −10 °C (14 °F). In summer
column4: the average maximum temperature is approximately 25 °C (77 °F)
column6: temperatures occasionally reach 35 to 40 °C (95 to 104 °F) in mid-summer in downtown. Although average precipitation and humidity during summer is relatively low
column7: there are infrequent yet heavy storms.

column1: Spring and autumn temperatures vary between 16 to 24 °C (61 to 75 °F)
column2: and precipitation during this time tends to be lower than in summer but with more frequent yet milder periods of rain.

column1: Chișinău is the seat of the Moldovan Orthodox Church

column1: Chișinău's growth plan was developed in the 19th century. In 1836 the construction of the Kishinev Cathedral and its belfry was finished. The belfry was demolished in Soviet times and was rebuilt in 1997. Chișinău also displays a tremendous number of orthodox churches and 19th-century buildings around the city such as Ciuflea Monastery or the Transfiguration Church. column1: The most popular form of internal transport in Moldova is generally the bus. Although the city has just three main terminals
column2: buses generally serve as the means of transport between cities in and outside of Moldova. Popular destinations include Tiraspol
column3: Odessa (Ukraine)
column4: Iași and Bucharest (Romania).

column1: The second most popular form of domestic transportation within Moldova is via railways. The total length of the network managed by Moldovan Railway CFM (as of 2009) is 1
column2: 232 kilometres (766 miles). The entire network is single track and is not electrified. The central hub of all railways is Chișinău Central Railway Station. There is another smaller railway station – Revaca located on the city's ends.

column1: Chișinău Railway Station has an international railway terminal with connections to Bucharest
column2: Kyiv
column3: Minsk
column4: Odessa
column7: Varna and St. Petersburg. Due to the simmering conflict between Moldova and the unrecognised Transnistria republic the rail traffic towards Ukraine is occasionally stopped.

column1: There is wide trolleybus network operating as common public transportation within city. From 1994
column2: Chișinău saw the establishment of new trolleybus lines
column3: as well as an increase in capacity of existing lines
column4: to improve connections between the urban districts. The network comprises 22 trolleybus lines being 246 km (153 mi) in length. Trolleybuses run between 05:00 and 03:00. There are 320 units daily operating in Chișinău. However the requirements are as minimum as 600 units. Trolleybus ticket costs at about 2 lei (ca. $0.11). It is the cheapest method of transport within Chișinău municipality.

column1: There are 29 lines of buses within Chișinău municipality. At each public transportation stops there is attached a schedule for buses and trolleybuses. There are approximately 330 public transportation stops within Chișinău municipality. There is a big lack of buses inside city limits
column2: with only 115 buses operating within Chișinău.
privately operated minibuses known as "rutieras" generally follow the major bus and trolleybus routes and appear more frequently.
there are 1100 units of minibuses operating within Chișinău. Minibuses services are priced the same as buses – 3 lei for a ticket (ca. $0.18).
